none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, August 8, 1884
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, August 8, 1884
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 18 Louis L. McInnis Papers
State Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas

en: Letter from H. H. Dinwiddie, Chairman of the Faculty at the State Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, to Louis L. McInnis dated August 8, 1884. Dinwiddie reports on his recent activities including an address about the college to a Grange meeting near Reagan, optimistic prospects for increased enrollment, and the locations of various faculty members. The letter provides insight into promotional efforts for the fledgling college and personal correspondence between academic leadership during the institution's early years.

body.value:
[Header]

STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE
— OF TEXAS —
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

H. H. DINWIDDIE,
Chairman of the Faculty.

College Station, Texas, Aug. 8 1884.

My dear McInnis

Yours of the 4th is before
me. I got home Wednesday.
Tuesday I spent at a large
Grange meeting near Reagan.
At 11 oclock I addressed
them on the subject of the
College. I struck out boldly
without M.S. and talked
for an hour and ten minutes.
They gave me the closest
attention during the entire time
I think they took to the
College finely. From every
quarter come the most cheerin

**Analyzing and Transcribing the Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's what I've got. I'm looking at this handwritten letter and breaking it down. First, I see the header: "STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE," then a line that says "-- OF TEXAS --," and then "(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)" which is smaller text. Below that, I see "H. H. DINWIDDIE," also in smaller text, and below that "Chairman of the Faculty." Alright, then there's the dateline: "College Station, Texas, Aug. 8 1884." The "188" part is printed, and the "4" looks like it was written in. Then, the salutation: "My dear McInnis". The body of the letter is next. I need to make sure I get the transcription perfect. The letter says, "Yours of the 4th is before me. I got home Wednesday. Tuesday I spent at a large Grange meeting near Reagan. At 11 oclock I addressed them on the subject of the College. I struck out boldly without M.S. and talked for an hour and ten minutes. They gave me the closest attention during the entire time I think they took to the College finely. From every quarter come the most cheerin". Now, time to make sure I transcribe everything correctly. The handwriting is fairly clear, but I want to be 100% accurate. Okay, "Aug. 8" is clear, and the "4" in "1884" is definitely handwritten. The "McInnis" handwriting is clear, "M" is distinct and capital, "c" is small, the "I" is large and clear, "nnis". The "4" in "4th" has a superscript "th". The text "Wednesday" is clear. "Tuesday" is clear. "Grange" in "Grange meeting" is capitalized. "Reagan" is clear. "11 oclock" - the words "o" and "clock" are connected as "oclock". "M.S." has two periods. "finely" is clear. And, oh, "cheerin" is cut off at the edge of the page. So I must stop where the text stops: "cheerin". Let's make a draft with the HTML allowed tags. Okay, first let's transcribe the letter: [Header] STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE

STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE
— OF TEXAS —
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

H. H. DINWIDDIE,
Chairman of the Faculty.

College Station, Texas, Aug. 8 1884.

My dear McInnis

Yours of the 4th is before
me. I got home Wednesday.
Tuesday I spent at a large

reports of our prospects and
I think we will be crowded
next year. Profs. Bringhurst
and Whipprecht are now her[e]
Dr. Read and Col. Cole are a[t]
the Confed. reunion in Dallas.
Smith is travelling in Central
Texas. Mrs. D. did not return
with me. I go to Galveston
Tuesday. Kind regards to
Mrs. M.S. They are getting
up all sorts of attractions at
Philadelphia. Exasperating
that we cant go.

[Signature]

Ever Truly Yours -
L. L. McInnis

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's my interpretation of this handwritten letter. My initial thought is to tackle this methodically, breaking down each element. 1. **Analyze the Image:** It's an old letter, handwritten in cursive. The paper is aged, with stains and some tears, especially along the right edge. That tear is important, I need to account for any words or letters potentially lost there. 2. **Transcription:** Now, to transcribe this, line by line. * **Line 1:** "reports of our prospects and" – Easy enough, it appears to be “reports of our prospects and.” * **Line 2:** "I think we will be crowded" – Clear: “I think we will be crowded.” * **Line 3:** "next year. Profs. Bringhurst" – "next year." is clear. Then "Profs." which is likely an abbreviation of “Professors.” And the surname is “Bringhurst.” I'm familiar with a "Prof. Bringhurst" from Texas A&M history, which, given the context mentioning "Dr. Read", "Col. Cole", and locations like "Dallas" and "Galveston," seems very likely to be a fit. * **Line 4:** "and Whipprecht are now her[e]" – "and" is clear. The name looks like “Whipprecht.” I also recall a Professor Whipprecht at Texas A&M. Now, the end of the line is problematic because of the paper tear. It looks like “her[e],” the 'e' being cut off. * **Line 5:** "Dr. Read and Col. Cole are a[t]" – "Dr. Read", "and", "Col. Cole" all straightforward. The end of the line, again, is torn. "a[t]" looks correct as a best fit for the cut-off letter. * **Line 6:** "the Confed. reunion in Dallas." – "the," "Confed." (likely for Confederate), "reunion", "in", and "Dallas." are all clear and make sense. * **Line 7:** "Smith is travelling in Central" – "Smith", "is", "travelling" (note the double "l"), "in", and "Central" are all standard. * **Line 8:** "Texas. Mrs. D. did not return" – “Texas.” is the first, the "Mrs. D." is clear. The word “return” is a bit messy, the “t” is uncrossed which is very common in fast cursive, so despite that, It does read: "r-e-t-u-r-n". * **Line 9:** "with me. I go to Galveston" – "with me." is clear. "I go to Galveston" is also clear. * **Line 10:** "Tuesday. Kind regards to" – “Tuesday.” And "Kind regards to" is very easy. * **Line 11:** "Mrs. M.S. They are getting" – The "Mrs." is clear. Then, "M.S.". It looks like it could be "M.S." or "M.J.". Let's look closely - the shape. It does appear to be an "S". * **Line 12:** "up all sorts of attractions at" – "up all sorts of attractions at" (attractions is written "attractios" or similar, looks like "attractions"). * **Line 13:** "Philadelphia. Exasperating" – “Philadelphia.” And "Exasperating" (is spelled correctly). * **Line 14:** "that we cant go." – "that we can't go." is clear. * **Line 15:** "Ever Truly Yours -" – "Ever Truly Yours -". It looks as though "Yours" is followed by a dash. 3. **Signature:** * The signature is "L. L. McInnis".
